reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game made me punch my monitor, but then I bought a new one so I could keep playing.

This top-down, wilderness survival will have you hooked in an hour! You'll spend hours on one save and have it taken away in the blink of an eye by a Pirate Ghost. There is a vast world to explore that will bring you hours of headaches trying to navigate. The never ending battle to find clean drinking water might turn you away, but if your persistent you'll uncover new islands and their mysteries.

10/10 would buy this for my enemies.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game. In fact I was actively watching the countdown to steam release at work just waiting to get home and get it. was playing 1.9.2 beta at work when it was slow once. My superviser saw it and decided to give it a whirl. he spawned next to a fire elemental and almost instantly died. I coulden't stop laughing.

I have played this game on and off since a few years back and I can say that it is not for everybody, but for anyone that this game does suit, it suits like a custom tailored Hugo Boss. Creative, exciting and tactical, it is everything you want from a refreshingly unique roguelike/survival game... except maybe a little easy. you might not agree if you haven't played it before but the game is all about progressive knowledge and discovery, so once you know what you need to do to survive its fairly easy to do so if you take things slow and think ahead. It has great potential and I would love to see some event like situations and more diversity in the future!

10/10 would repair glass bottle with stone hammer again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Thank you to the developer for kindly providing a review key.
---

Note: as of 4/23/16, great majority of my time was spent with the older free online version (still available if you want to try it btw), although the review considers both.

---

In the endless sea of clones in the roguelike/lite survival/crafting genre, Wayward is a sight for sore eyes. This title has been in active developement for some time now, and it definately shows. First-and-foremost, what is most notable about Wayward that sets it apart from other similiar titles is that it is turn-based.

Essentially, you are stranded on an island and must survive. Sound familiar? Sure. While Wayward seems to share similiar characteristics with other clones - it is truly exceptional. What really makes this title stand out is an excellent user-interface, a truly deep crafting system, and steep-yet-fair difficulty which combine to create a really addicting experience. While I have played countless survival/crafting clones over the years, nothing has given me that thrilling experience of trying to survive and learn mechanics similiar to my first time playing Don't Starve. With that being said, this isn't Don't Starve - it has a personality all of its own. I would highly recommend trying the free version - get past the moderate learning curve and then the addiction begins :)

Pros:
+Everything is fairly logical. With each death you will have an 'aha' moment, where you will almost immediately know how to correct your actions on your next run. This really makes an addicting experience.
+The user interface is really easy to use and makes a complex system fairly intuitive.
+Tons of items and crafting recipes that make sense.
+Tutorial is a warm welcome from the web version.
+Graphics are well done and fitting.
+The moderate-to-steep difficulty is great, and keeps you coming back for more.
+Super cheap asking price for the quality hours you can get out.

Cons:
-Sometimes I get stuck with trying to figure out a simple crafting recipe. Perhaps a recipe list has been added in-game since the Steam launch, but I haven't found it yet. I usually just alt+tab to the Wiki, but this can be tedious at times. Once you learn the recipes, this is not a big deal.
-Just be aware this is a much slower paced game than others in this genre. Not necessarily a 'con' per se, but be aware.
-Sometimes movement can feel janky - ie. accidentally walking into a fire pit or bumping into trees and gathering stuff you don't want to.

If you like survival/crafting games, and enjoy turn-based play, this is a no-brainer. This stands far ahead of the others. I totally recommend this game.

I have played this game since their initial release on their site, I would say I have at least 100 hours logged into it. It is by far one of the best rogue-likes I have played.

Pros:
- Fun
- Time consuming, but you can leave at any second since it is turn based.
- Long in development, Free before release 2.0
- Modding support
- No lag
- Logical
- Beautiful pixel art graphics
- Super nice devs, does twitch streams
- Time and effort put into every single aspect
- Completely open development, you can see their progress on trello (I was following the steam 2.0 release on there)
- Low priced.

Cons:
- You may smash your computer when you die, but you will likely buy another computer to play it again.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI had limited expectations for this game, which is a good policy for any purchase; but it defied all of them. If you're a fan of procedural survival games (Neo Scavenger, Starbound, freakin' Minecraft, etc.), then you will love this. The graphics are conservative but well-kept-up, the terrain is actually convincing, and the rogue-like feel adds an additional element that works quite well wtih it all. The soundtrack is also very professionally done. For he price, it's a must!

It's a rogueish game with survival as a key aspect of the game. I think it should be obvious to developers now that people like to hit escape to get to the exit menu not clear the UI, also the scrolling in the UI can make a player want to pull their hair out while trying to get to the third row of the crafting menu ( something a scroll locking system can make go away)

The most troubling thing in the game is that it is turn based so it's a pain in the ♥♥♥ when the game decides to make the player go crazy and depending on the automatic turns the game can make the player go it can make the player randomly run into danger. . . basically it seems the game doesn't clear commands or button presses so it cues up; up left right down commands and randomly chooses a command order or something. . . basically you are playing and going right right and you press d" to go right and then you watch your player go up

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been watching this game for awhile. I played the free betas before the Steam release quite a lot. So what can I tell you about Wayward? Well, it's a turn-based island survival game. There's a lot of crafting, there's a lot to discover, and there's a hell of a lot of danger. This game does not hold your hand.

The crafting system is surprisingly pretty easy to use. You make discoveries through crafting basic things that guide you towards what resources you will need and what you will want to consider crafting yet. The hints that pop up give you a bit of insight, but it leaves most of the hard work up to you.

Survival is hard. It's easy to starve, it's easy to become dehydrated, it's easy to become overtired or overencumbered, and it's sure as hell easy to run into an enemy that you weren't ready to face. The first little while you play the game will consist of you figuring out the basics. If you're turned on by games that force you to die a ton before you can actually get anywhere, this game won't be for you.

All that being said, the game is crazy charming. The graphics are very simple and cute. The sound effects are very basic, but certainly not bad at all. There isn't a whole lot of animation, but somehow the game doesn't need it. The music is actually fantastic. It coats the game in an atmosphere the seems to flesh out the game world in a way that it wouldn't be otherwise. It almost reminds me of the Donkey Kong Country 2 OST or something.

It's a great little survival game that's always growing. It's hard as hell, but it's harder not to love it. Not only that, it's pretty darn cheap. A very easy recommendation for me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've got a decent amount of time put into the game so I think I can say thoroughly how I feel about it.
First off about the earlier version of the game I must have played it equally if not more hours than the steam 2.0 version; Wayward 2.0 is a huge leap in improvement over the earlier version, many bugs were fixed, art was improved, movement controls feel a lot more natural, and it has modding available which just opens the game to endless possibilities. I may even try making a simple mod or two.

For the price of $7.99 for what the game offers currently is a definite steal and it supports the team to work on it further down the road. They've already intended to continually add to it whether or not they make millions. They interact with the community through Twitch streams, and show what they intend on adding through their Wayward Trello.

Okay so with all that said maybe you are completely new to the game and haven't played the earlier version; this is a roguelike, you die and lose your world then you need to start a whole new one. It's a bit of a challenge for a new player, you will probably die the first night and perhaps again the second night, but that's okay! You'll learn from your deaths and continue to improve in survival until you get to the end game which is full of riches!

Pros:
-Can spend hours playing.

-Can save and resume whenever. (thank you turn base!)

-Each world is a new experience since it auto generates.

-Crafting, there are a ton of things to craft.

-I love that I can hotkey all my windows to one button to open and close my inventory, equipment,  crafting, milestones and skills all at once.

-The caves are extremely fun exploring, more so than the world above in my opinion. Having true darkness in a game that can only be illuminated by a torch is the best.

-Hand Drill is probably by far the best item in the game. This has to be the biggest pro of them all as this item has nearly no weight to it and provides so many fire starting.


Cons:
-Combat is simple yet not simple. You walk into creatures to attack the complexity of combat comes down to which weapons you have equiped. Although since the devs are continually adding to the game and modders will have a shot the combat could get really interesting.

-It's still early access so there's very few choice of mods and whatever small kinks are in the game are still being iron out, although any kinks there are get patched quickly or aren't noticed through normal gameplay.

-Early game at times can feel unfair only leaving you the option of running and hiding from creatures. This is mostly a personal peeve, the game needs danger of course.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have a strange relationship with this game. Been playing the free version every now and then for about 2 years now. I'd play for 10-15 hours, reach endgame, get a bit bored with how OP my character gets, put the game down, then repeat the process every few months and/or after a couple of updates.

I might be a bit biased, but for all the time I've spent playing this thing, I'd be happy to shell out 7-10 bucks.. and if it means more frequent updates, then that's just icing on the cake.

EDIT: Updates have been going strong, and the devs have been very transparent throughout the whole process on their Trello page. Cheers to those guys.

Pros:
+ challenging yet sensible survival mechanics with a good learning curve
+ high replay value - always feels fun returning to the game after forgetting about it and stressing out for a while on some other games
+ lightweight.. can practically run on a potato
+ active devs that actually look like they care

Cons:
- UI can get a bit cluttered after getting tons of items
- steam version still feels a bit same-y to the free version (gets better with each update though)

The free version's still up on their site. There's already a good number of changes on the steam version, but the core mechanics are still pretty much the same, so you might want to give it a try there first. If you like it, why not give it a little push here on steam? :^)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Pay no attention to the playtime above, I've played the non-Steam betas of this game for at least 40+ hours in total.)

Wayward is an island survival roguelike, with heavy emphasis on the survival part. (For those of you who like ancient obscure freeware, it's basically the game Schiffbruch but with many more features and a lot more to discover.) It's the kind of game where you can die within the first five minutes, or do awesomely for an hour and then die to some silly mistake. Easily frustrated people be warned-- this game will kick your butt!

If you can get past that, however, Wayward is a game that can be strangely peaceful, punctuated with moments of intense drama. You've finally finished building a little shelter of wooden walls and you got a campfire started...but oh no! There's a zombie at your doorstep. Do you hurriedly craft a snare, or run out the back of your shelter and hope to lose it in the nearby woods?

You got a ton of awesome loot in the cave, but a pirate ghost is suddenly chasing after you!

Oh no, you forgot to get a second glass bottle or flask before constructing your water desalinator-- how are you going to carry water from the ocean to distill??

You forgot to repair your axe, and now you have to dig stone with your bare hands! It's okay though, you have 50% in mining...

What's great is that even when you inevitably screw up and die, there's always something to be learned. Fight spiders and snakes before taking on a shark. Supplement your health with berries and sutures while you're hurriedly running around trying to find freshwater to save yourself from dehydration. Don't walk into the campfire because it REALLY hurts. It's a game that appears simple on the surface, but is actually complex and has quite a bit to discover.

The best part is, there are many paths to success. You can become a burly tough guy and beat up all the monsters. You can build a small farm and create your own pixely homestead. You can be an explorer and hunt after that sweet, sweet ectoplasm to enchant your armor. You can build a raft and explore the seas, collecting treasure and fighting krakens.

Or you can just die a bunch. That will probably happen too. As with many roguelikes, this game needs to be approached with a good sense of humor and a bit of an inner masochist. I recommend watching streams, or playing with friends if it gets frustrating-- it's hard not to laugh when you build an awesome cabin in the woods, only to have a fire elemental burn it all down. Sometimes you accidentally drink the unpurified water, and you get poisoned. And sometimes you just can't hit that rat, no matter how many times you try....

I've been following Wayward's development since at least 1.5, and it's wonderful to see how far it's come! The graphics are even more beautiful, in all their pixely glory, the 80bit music is still adventurous and lends an aura of wonder and imagination, and the gameplay is better streamlined.

My main complaints are mostly cosmetic-- for example, the font size is a bit small still, and the various game windows you have to navigate can, at times, be overwhelming or feel cluttered, especially if you're new to the game. And I do unfortunately still have some lag, even though i'm using a newer computer than i had the last time i played the 1.9.2 pre-Steam release (it appears to have something to do with how much weight i'm carrying? I'm confused). But all of these issues are to be expected in a beta and can be ironed out easily.

IMO, the biggest and most promising new feature in this release is the Steam Workshop support! The possibilities for this game are now endless. Even before this release, there were quite a few nice mods on the Unlok forums. It will only get better!

Please, grab this game while it's on sale! 7 bucks is a steal, and if you don't like it at first, you can come back to it tomorrow, or in a week, because every game is a little different.

The island awaits...

Edit: For people who are mad about a free game going paid, there's still a free version of the game available on the official website. http://www.unlok.ca/wayward/introducing-wayward-free/

Also, because you all are being petty for complaining about a game that has probably given you 30+ hours of enjoyment, here's a sampling of what you could buy for the same cost as Wayward!

Two frozen Pizzas
Three glass bottles of Coke.
Two large bags of chips.
Two chicken breasts.
Almost two bus tickets.
Two beers if you buy them in a store, maybe enough for one if you buy at a pub.
One high quality coffee at a coffeehouse.
Four liters of gas (about 1.05 gallons).
3/5 of a movie ticket, or less depending on the theater (LITERALLY AN HOUR OF ENTERTAINMENT)
1.5 coffees from Starbucks
0.5 of a new shirt
0.25 of a cheap pair of jeans
Half of a CD (LITERALLY 30 MINUTES OF ENTERTAINMENT)
Half a barbie doll
1/4 of a board game
1 Book, used

Yeah, shame on you for not supporting this extremely dedicated developer-- one who worked on this for three+ years without getting paid a cent, with what amounts to a PITTANCE.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

already played it 100+ hours on the site, will probably play it 100+ on the steam version.

Wayward is a survival game, overused genre these days. But Wayward offers some nice stuff.

- everything gives xp, making you better at what you do, stronger, last longer.
- you can set up base everywhere you want, you can even make your own island if you are willing to work for piling up the amounts of sand needed for it.
- you can survive whatever way you want, kill monsters, create a farm, grow mushrooms, or a little bit of everything.
- plenty of strong monsters and hidden treasure to keep you interested for a while after you survived the first few weeks.
- the game says it takes about 10+ hours to reach endgame, but you can easily get 50+ hours in, building your base up, lveling your stats or getting ingrediënts for one of the 200+ crafting recipes the game has,

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wayward, Free Web version vs. Steam version

i gotta say, i touched this back around 2-3 years ago, it was an interesting concept back then and it was free to try. it had its bugs and lack of goal and such, but it was still a good game to play if you just wanted to chill and take your time.

now, the new version has many of the big bugs fixed the free web version has/had. updated art assets make the game feel more than just the mass following of retro style indie games. its still early access as of writing this so it has its bugs but so far development team has been very responsive in the steam forums.

if you liked stardew valley, minecraft, terraria, this is a good inbetween game so you dont burn out on the others.


the price: i cant say either way about the price, the devs hosted it for free for 3 years or so pre- 2.0 beta. 7$ seems miniscule a charge to own it via steam. if 7$ is too steep a price for you to splurge on a game, might look inward at the source of that problem.

overall, its game worth owning, either now or when its done if you lost trust in all EA titles. but as its been said, there is a free web version you can try to see if its your thing, the differences are very minor in terms of mechanics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

9.5/10. Including the free online version of the game, I've put in probably 50 hours total. The game is smooth, the interface is updated and clean, the mechanics are balanced (besides zombies. ♥♥♥♥ zombies.) and there is always something for you to attempt to accomplish. If you like roguelike survival games and/or pixelated games in general, you'll get a kick out of Wayward. My only (very miniscule) complaint is when starting a new game, all my interface windows I've spent so much time aligning and putting in order are completely reset and it's very tiresome resizing and remaking the layout I had before. I haven't encountered any bugs that I know of so I would consider it bug-free, so there's that too.

Just a little P.S.

The game is challenging! Don't give up after your first few deaths because you should be dying multiple times before eventually finding a good set up that you can thrive and survive with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been enjoying this game quite a bit, but it has a few flaws which could be fixed. I understand this game is in early access and the devs are still working on the game, but that's why I'm writing the review, to hopefully get in touch and get my points across.

Currently the tutorial is pretty bad, if you're a new player I don't think it will help you much at all. The tutorial teaches you the bare bone basics and that's it. I believe that it should teach you how to get your first piece of iron (not wrought) gear. Since this is already a hard process without looking up how to do it. I feel this would be enough to perhaps even propel a new player into the late game.

Chests don't work the way I think they should. This may be just a personal thing, but I think that if you are doing crafting and you're within a distance of the chest (obviously small to keep it realistic) that you should be able to use the items from that chest. Just a convenience thing to make it easier to do crafting at your base. On a somewhat similar note, backpacks are over complicated, they should just add extra carrying capacity.

Another pet peeve of mine is what gets used as a sharp edge. I have had gold swords and iron axes go out on me from crafting sprees, so either make it where you can pick what is used, or have the worst item be used first (small rock-golden sword)

I'm pretty sure I already saw that this was in the works, but it would be awesome if sprites looked different as you put items on. Right now it just kind of feels weird when you have full iron armor and you're walking around with a tee shirt on.

Again, I understand that the game is still in the works, and I thinks the game is a lot of fun and worth the money, but I hope the devs look over these suggestions and think them over.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game could be compared a lot to something like Don't Starve. A very challenging survival experience where each permadeath teaches you the things you need to know so you could get a little bit further every time.

My main thought is that this looks and feels a lot like a browser game you'd find on a site like Kongregate but in all honesty i've seen browser games with smoother, more streamlined gameplay and better UI design. It may not seem like something to complain about but it's death by a thousand cuts if you are easily annoyed or perplexed by things like searching in your crafting menu for a minute to find a thing to start a fire with or why you even have to do so in order to do something as simple as lighting a furnace.

I hope the devs work on making the gameplay more streamlined and cleaning up the user interface to make things easier to navigate.

If you enjoy highly challenging survival games like Don't Starve than you might like this one. If you are put off by the permadeath and clunky gameplay than give it a miss.

Thumbs down because it still has a ways to go before I can recommend it to everyone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great time-waster! It doesn't require you to progress so far to save or anything, and you can set simple goals for a given session, so I like to play this when I don't have time for more involved games.

The progression is a bit all over the place. I'd find myself stagnating for a while until I found that one message in a bottle that would give me a crafting recipe I needed, but it was still fun just exploring the caves and islands while building up my humble stronghold on the island I started on.

The game itself is fairly bug-free. There are gameplay mechanics still being changed, given that it's early access, but I didn't encounter anything really game-breaking. I think it's worth the money already!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First Impression Video:

https://youtu.be/-3heL09YSj4

Wayward is an enjoyable turn based survival game. It has everything you could want: procedural generation, crafting, and smashing rats in the face.

Wayward is definitely not an easy game, but it's also not a game that will beat you down for one wrong move. You have to work to get some meager living and a single rat can push you into a rush to find a suture. Bleeding out ain't no fun people.

At this point, Wayward is a fully fledged game. It needs some serious overhauls to the tutorial, but if you're willing to try and fail, this game is a fun time. I haven't found any bugs in the game so far.

One negative point that i would give this game is that it can put you in situations that you can't survive in. Being placed on an island with no rock (which is needed for every tool except wood spears, and harvesting without a tool can hurt you) means that you're doomed to a slow death.

Overall, Wayward is a seriously fun game. If you're into survival and crafting games, it's definitely worth picking up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wayward is a turn-based survival and crafting game with procedural world generation which would be well worth playing at 2-3xs the price. At $8 it's a bargain, especially for an Early Access Game this well developed.

The world is interesting and worth exploring, although the backstory is sparse. Crafting is well thought-out and strikes an excellent balance between reality and gameplay. Crafting recipe discovery is a very strong draw, and you can build atop your early failures with a system that brings what you learned the previous playthrough into each new start (unless you’d rather start from scratch, which you can do!). There's a wide array of skills and possible gameplay strategies, although they are not all fully balanced just yet.

There are some bumpy spots, as expected of a game in development, but the dev team is incredibly responsive. I've yet to encounter any instability with the game engine. As I write this the in-game tutorial already does a good job of easing you into the survival gameplay. The difficulty spikes up fairly harshly right now, but balance is a moving target for any game in development. Modding is enthusiastically supported by the devs, who have provided tutorials and open-source examples to get the modding scene started.

This game has apparently been in-dev for years. You can play the previous version of this game for free on their website, and it should be a great demo. If you like the free version, quickly buy it on Steam to support their great team. They’re quick to reply to feedback and take suggestions seriously. They even provide a link to the team’s dev tracker tool, where you can watch each new update come together as it progresses.

I’ll say it again: if you happen to enjoy TBS, survival, crafting, exploration or just supporting an indie team doing good work, you could hardly do better than giving this game a try.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a great survival game.  It features hunger, thirst and day/night cycles and has many many skills to learn such as Blacksmithing, Fletching, Anatomy, Cooking, Clay Throwing, Glassmaking and about 12 more skills.  You discover crafting recipes as you collect items from the world which persist with you through each play-through.  The crafting system is very robust but sometimes tedious.  This game also features perma-death but there is a mod that allows for resurrection so you don't lose all your progress if you like to play that way.  The exploring is fun and monsters are challenging.  Base building is simple and there are a variety of objects with which to build your base.  You can also farm several food/medicinal items.  There are also boats that you can craft to sail to new islands or to new worlds.  All in all a very fun, addictive little game with active developer support and mod integration through the workshop.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was looking for a simple relaxing turn based game I could mess around with: garden, make a shed, wander around. Wayward was kind of overkill for my purposes and but its been a good fit. Plus its a damn fine game for $8.

Environments are appealing, the crafting system is robust, disease/thirst/hunger are interesting and complex mechanics. Inventory weight and durability might be a bit too realistic for me. I like that my character dones't just drink big gulps of seawater to replenish thirst. RPG skill ups that kind of remind me of Runescape. All in all the game is a lot bigger than I thought it'd be, maybe the simpler graphics allow the devs to focus on a fuller game world. I have yet to encounter a bug which is amazing for early access.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

Beta.

That pretty much sums up this experience. Is it bad? Not even close.

There's always a challenge, a real tough challenege to have an immersive world and yet keeping it free and non-linear. Survival games are always a tough place to be where you sacrifice open world play for some form of progression. Eventually, the kinks in these types games will smooth out.

This is def worth a try as it focuses more of real aspects than fantasy ones. (They're there though haha). The most important part of this game that will need better item organization (always a tough thing with these games) and better UI (fluid environment and action commands). Recommend if you are into roguelike and survival type games for sure.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been waiting years for this game to come out and it more than lives up to the original pre-alpha. With an exeptional soundtrack and a turn-based gameplay style that I have never before seen it is one of the most immersive adventure games I have played in years. It is top down Minecraft, it is Terraria flipped on it's head, it is perfect. My only complaint is that the ui boxes become opaque when moused over.

If you don't like dying a lot, don't buy it.
If you don't like difficult games, don't buy it.
If you don't like adventure games, don't buy it.
If you don't like situations where you know you won't survive, don't buy it.
If you don't like item decay systems, don't buy it.

If you are looking for a top-down, pixel art, unforgiving game, with an exceptional item decay system, buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wayward, at it's current state, is very enjoyable and quite different than anything I've played before (from Minecraft, Terraria, Final Fantasy, etc). I recommend it to anyone that enjoys old-school pixel graphic sandbox games with rpg, crafting, and building elements.

It is in alpha/beta phase, so just keep in mind that many things ought to change over time. Devs appear to be very professional and friendly, also active in the community (on reddit, Steam Discussions, their own webpage, etc) which is a huge plus. This little gem has great potential.

Things to consider:
- Turn-based (when ya move, craft, consume something, build, etc; other creatures move, time/game ticks forward)
- Very old-school pixel graphics (which I personally love)
- Lots of craftables, though building options are a bit limited right now.
- RPG elements: tons of different skills to level up as you use them/craft stuff, which increase your 'Talent' points (purple points to right of health points)
- Combat is very simple, so far. Ranged weapons and traps add a bit of tact to it.
- You will most likely die and it will most likely frustrate you
- Perma-death (you die, you have to start a new randomly generated world. I'd recommend the Reincarnate Mod, by dev in Workshop, to randomly respawn in same world so all your progress isn't down the drain. Though, your skills do carry over, no matter if you use mod or not)
- Micromanagement is tedious and clunky right now, takes a bit to get use to. As well as using some tools.
- Tutorial is very brief, the basic of the basics. No hand holding and you're left to figure most things out on your own. I don't mind it, but you may.
- Difficulty is sporadic, especially if you haven't read up on the mechanics. (Some folks find it very difficult while some find it very easy, though I wager that a lot of it depends where you randomly spawn at and what creatures randomly spawn in your vicinity).
- Difficulty does scale with your progression/Talent points (purple numbers by health), so keep that in mind. It means that stronger/different monsters can spawn and I believe their hp and damage does increase, but not too significantly.
- It's a lot like Minecraft, where I'd advise to mess around to figure out some things until ya die a few times, then take a few to read up on some tips/advice/game mechanics, etc before restarting again to ensure your survival.
- Music is great

Some folks have beat it pretty quick, indicating that it's not necessarily that long of a game (at the moment of development), but if you take your time, build a place or town or whatever, collect stuff, explore the large world, hunt down different monsters, etc; you should easily get 20 to maybe 30 hours or more before ya run out of stuff to do. Not considering the additional content that will most likely be added within the near future. ^.^
